misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling .close() on a Scanner instance only cleans up the memory or resources specifically used by that object without impacting the system-wide input source it was reading from.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, closing a Scanner that is wrapping an InputStream (like System.in) also closes that underlying stream. Since System.in is a global resource representing the keyboard input, closing it prevents any other part of the program from reading user input for the remaining duration of the program's execution.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that by including the variable names (v0, v1, t) in the prompt string, the computer establishes a logical connection between those labels and the subsequent values entered by the user.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java execution model treats the prompt string as an opaque sequence of characters to be displayed to the user. It does not parse the text to understand the context of the requested data. The program simply assigns whichever token appears next in the input stream to the next variable in the code's sequence, regardless of how the user interprets the prompt.
